SP.P: My Uncle and my Cousin both dead!—If this be so, Maria, my Ambition indeed will be satisfied, but my Happiness 'tis you only can bestow.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANTONY.
SP.P: Why, how is all this, Frederick? Sometimes he is a Lord, and sometimes he is none.—What is the Truth?

SP.SPEAKER: FREDERICK.
SP.P: This Letter, Sir, will explain it to you; indeed I wou'd recommend the Whole to your Perusal.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD LOVINGTON.
SP.P: In good Truth, I am thoroughly asham'd of this Disguise, and cou'd laugh as heartily as either of you at the ridiculous Figure I must have made in this Transaction.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANTONY.
SP.P: Well, there is some Sense in this. [Returning the Letter.] My Lord, I heartily congratulate you, and beg a thousand Pardons for my Incivility to you.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD LOVINGTON.
SP.P: Oh! Sir Antony, mention it not, lest you bring me to the Blush.—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANTONY.
SP.P: By my say-so, this is an Event that will make no small Figure upon Paper; I am only concern'd that my Part has not been so brilliant as I cou'd wish; but I must help that out in the Relation. This Jade Clara has cruelly disarrang'd my Matters; no where to be found, either by Land or Water: Well, well, we have not drag'd the Pond for nothing. Now Fre∣derick cou'd we but find where Clara,—pshaw—I mean where Miss Hartley has hid herself, I might dispose of both my Children at once. Ods Life! I wou'd it was come to that!

LG.L: When my Children are wedded all and gone,
With a this Way, that Way, and every Way;
And a happy Day will be that Day,
When they've left me to myself alone,
With a this Way, &c.
And I wou'd they were gone every one.
Then will I seek out for a Wife,
With a this Way, &c.
And a happy Day will be that Day,
When I renew a wedded Life,
With a this Way, &c.
For every Way I'll please my Wife.
But shou'd she prove wayward, pert and bold,
With a this Way, &c.
What a luckless Day wou'd be that Day,
When I lighted first upon a Scold,
With a this Way, &c.
Ah! what Way's left for me that am old!

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VIII.
DIV2.STAGE: OLIVIA enters with AMELIA brought in by a numerous Rabble of Peasants; HENRY following at some Dis∣tance.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANTONY.
SP.P: Heyday! who have we got here? Is the whole Parish stung with the Gadfly? What's the Matter with you all?

SP.SPEAKER: OLIVIA.
SP.P: Why these honest People have a strange Story to tell you, Sir Antony.

SP.SPEAKER: Ist PEASANT.
SP.P: Yes, and please your Worship, we have a strange Story to tell you: But things have gone very cross with us all this Harvest through; a Power of mildew'd Grain—Farmer Chaff's Horses are in a Manner eat up with the Botts, one and all—and Master Grubb's Cows are sorely pester'd with the Tail-worm; so that we are fit to think, please your Worship, that the poor Beasties are Hag-ridden, as it were.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANTONY to AMELIA.
SP.P: Well, Child, is it you have done all this? I see you are a Dealer in the Black Art.—

SP.SPEAKER: Ist PEASANT.
SP.P: Noa, your Honour, we don't directly say so; but we were a little dubilous about the young Woman, so we'll pray your Worship to examine her a bit.

SP.SPEAKER: FREDERICK.
SP.P: O Neighbours, leave her to me; I'll examine her.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st PEASANT.
SP.P: We are much beholden to your Honour: Pray you now, young Gentleman, ask her why she wears that black Thing athwart her Face, whereof I can take my Bible Oath on't that she is sometimes as sightly a young Woman to look at, as ever my Eyes beheld; and why she keeps hanging about the Grove at the Bottom of the Paddock; there can be no good Intent in that.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANTONY.
SP.P: Go, ye simple People, get home, and leave the young Woman with us.

SP.SPEAKER: HENRY,
SP.P: I am asham'd, Gaffer Dowling, to see an old Man like you make himself such a Fool. [Exeunt Peasants.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANTONY.
SP.P: Well, young Woman, let us know why you are masked, and what your Business is in these Parts?

SP.SPEAKER: AMELIA.
SP.P: My Profession, Sir, is Fortune-telling; I deal with the Stars.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANTONY.
SP.P: I rather believe 'tis with the Moon.

SP.SPEAKER: AMELIA.
SP.P: Give me your Hands. [Taking Sir Antony with one Hand, and Frederick with the other.

LG.L: You love, and are belov'd again. [To Frederick.
You love, alas! but love in vain. [To Sir Ant.
The Grove.—The Garden was the Scene.
You've been to blame—
Oh! fie for Shame,
With Hairs so grey to wear a Head so green▪
Your Maid is fled.—Your Mistress gone:
Yet both these Losses are but one:
I, who conceal'd her, can restore.
Lament!—Rejoice!
Here is my Choice!
Come take, Oh! take, and never quit me more.

SP.SPEAKER: FREDERICK.
SP.P: O transporting Surprize! Do I behold thee? do I again embrace thee, my dear, my destin'd Amelia?

SP.SPEAKER: MARIA.
SP.P: Amelia—?

SP.SPEAKER: LORD LOVINGTON.
SP.P: What do I see? my Cousin Emily Hartley? Why this is fortunate beyond Description.

SP.SPEAKER: MARIA.
SP.P: Bless me, my Lord, is Miss Hartley your Cousin?

SP.SPEAKER: LORD LOVINGTON.
SP.P: Even so—and if my Hopes don't flatter me, our Alliance is in a way to be improved.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANTONY.
SP.P: What do I hear? And are you, that was my Clara, the Daughter of Sir William Hartley?

SP.SPEAKER: AMELIA.
SP.P: I am, Sir, and can you be generous enough to for∣give my Preference of your Son before you?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANTONY.
SP.P: Oh! no more of that I charge you. 'Tis well we are wiser than our Children, for certainly they have some unaccountable Advantages over us.

SP.SPEAKER: FREDERICK.
SP.P: O my Amelia, I have News for thee, which I flatter myself you will be pleased with: your Friends are impatient to receive you, and have consented to our Union.

SP.SPEAKER: AMELIA.
SP.P: Then is my Joy compleat. Now had I but a Friend that cou'd relate to them this Day's Events, as they really have happen'd—

SP.SPEAKER: HENRY.
SP.P: You have a Friend, Madam, an humble and a faith∣ful one; reay to undertake that Office, or any other you can lay upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: AMELIA.
SP.P: I thank thee, my good Henry, and will accept your Services. Frederick, I have much to tell thee of this Youth, whom I desire you will love for my sake.

SP.SPEAKER: FREDERICK.
SP.P: I know him well: his Fortune shall be my Care.

SP.SPEAKER: HENRY.
SP.P: Thank Heaven! I shall now be absent, when she is married. [Aside.] [Exit Henry.

SP.SPEAKER: AMELIA.
SP.P: Sir Antony, as I crost your Lawn I found your Harvest Folks assembled at their Sports; the Serenity of the Evening, and the Chearfulness of the Scene, compose the most agreeable sight in Nature.

SP.SPEAKER: MARIA.
SP.P: Oh! by all Means, Sir, let us go thither; Joy is pleasing in whatsoever Shape it appears.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR ANTONY.
SP.P: Let this then be a Day of general Happiness!

SP.SPEAKER: LORD LOVINGTON.
SP.P: For my own Part I contemplate all rural Pastimes with Reverence and Delight. The natural Expressions of an innocent Joy in a free and happy People are in my most grateful Oblation that can be offer'd in return for such Blessings.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Lov.
SP.L: Scenes of Plenty, Scenes of Peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.L: Meads, where Flocks and Herds disporting

SP.SPEAKER: Chor.
SP.L: Scenes of Plenty, Scenes of Peace.
